Choose the Right One
January 17, 2024 · COMPARISON

Framer AI vs Durable: Quality vs Speed

I spent 26 hours testing both. Built multiple sites on each. One gives stunning designs you can't export. The other generates functional sites in 30 seconds that look dated.

The one-sentence answer:
Use Framer if you care about design. Portfolios, marketing sites, anything visual. Slower and more expensive, but the output is gorgeous.

Use Durable if you care about speed. Local businesses, MVPs, quick validation. Not pretty, but live in under a minute.

The fundamental difference

Framer and Durable sit at opposite ends of the AI builder spectrum. Framer prioritizes design quality and customization. Durable prioritizes speed and simplicity.

Framer: Generate a site in 2-5 minutes, then spend 2-4 hours refining. You get pixel-perfect control over everything. The result looks like a professional designer built it.

Durable: Generate a complete site in 28 seconds. Done. What you see is basically what you get. Limited customization, but it's live and functional.

Framer AI:

Best for design quality and portfolios

Durable AI:

Best for speed and simplicity

Verdict: Framer for design, Durable for speed

Quick comparison

Metric Framer AI Durable Winner
Design quality 9.2/10 6.5/10 Framer
Generation speed 3-5 minutes 28 seconds Durable
Ease of use 7/10 9/10 Durable
Customization 9.5/10 4/10 Framer
PageSpeed score 98/100 85/100 Framer
Export options $25/month tier None Framer
Monthly cost $15-25 $12-20 Durable

Where Framer wins

Stunning designs

Framer's AI understands spacing, typography, and visual hierarchy. The generated sites look like a human designer spent hours on them. Smooth animations, thoughtful micro-interactions, professional polish.

Durable's designs look functional. Generic business templates. Nothing offensive, but nothing memorable. If your brand is design-driven, Framer is the only choice.

Full customization

Move anything anywhere. Change fonts, colors, animations. Framer's visual editor feels like using Figma—predictable and powerful. You can create custom hover states, scroll animations, complex interactions.

Durable lets you change colors and swap content, but that's about it. Layout changes are limited. If Framer gives you 100% control, Durable gives you 20%.

Excellent performance

My test sites: Framer at 98/100 PageSpeed, loads in under 1 second. Durable at 85/100, loads in ~1.5s. Both are fast, but Framer is exceptional—better Core Web Vitals, smoother interactions.

Interaction designer

Framer has a built-in tool for creating animations and micro-interactions. Hover effects, scroll animations, page transitions—designed visually, no code needed. Durable has none of this.

Where Durable wins

Lightning fast

28 seconds to a live site. Not "ready to customize"—actually live. Name your business, answer 3 questions, hit generate. Done. Framer can't match this speed.

Very simple

No learning curve. Generate and done. My 65-year-old dad built his contractor site in Durable without help. Framer takes 2-3 hours to learn the basics.

Built-in CRM

Email tools, contact management, invoicing—all included. Framer is just a website builder. Durable is trying to be a business platform. If you need simple CRM, Durable wins.

Affordable

$12/month vs $15-25 for Framer. Not a huge difference, but every dollar counts for small businesses. And Durable includes more features at that price.

The lock-in problem

Both have the same fatal flaw: you can't leave.

Framer lets you export, but only on the $25/month plan. And even then, you're exporting React code tied to Framer's ecosystem—not portable HTML/CSS. If you leave, you're rebuilding.

Durable doesn't export at all. Your site lives on their servers, uses their platform, and if you stop paying, it disappears. Period.

Bottom line: If building a long-term business asset matters to you, neither tool is ideal. But if you're testing an idea or need something live tomorrow, they're both fine—just know you're renting, not owning.

So which should you use?

Choose Framer if:

  • You're a designer or creative professional
  • Design quality matters more than speed
  • You need animations and micro-interactions
  • You're building a portfolio or marketing site
  • You're willing to spend 2-3 hours learning

Choose Durable if:

  • You're a local business (plumber, dentist, bakery)
  • You need a site live in under 5 minutes
  • You don't care about design awards
  • You're testing an MVP or business idea
  • You want built-in CRM and email tools

Choose neither if:

  • You need e-commerce (use 10Web)
  • You want to own your code (use WordPress)
  • You're on a tight budget (use free options)
  • You're doing white-label client work

Bottom line

Framer makes the prettiest sites. If design matters, pay the extra and deal with the learning curve. Your site will look professional.

Durable makes sites fastest. If you just need something online now and don't care about aesthetics, it's perfect for that.

They're not competitors. Framer is for design-led projects. Durable is for speed-led projects. Pick based on what matters more: how it looks or how fast it's live.
